content.text: [[INLINE_IMAGE|//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Tripolitania.jpg/250px-Tripolitania.jpg|//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Tripolitania.jpg/375px-Tripolitania.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Tripolitania.jpg/500px-Tripolitania.jpg 2x|A 1913 map of Italian Tripolitania; green indicates agricultural areas|h191|w250]]

items.text: **Italian Tripolitania** was an [[LINK|lang_en|Kingdom_of_Italy_(1861%E2%80%931946)|Italian]] colony, located in present-day western [[LINK|lang_en|Libya|Libya]], that existed from 1911 to 1934. It was part of the territory conquered from the [[LINK|lang_en|Ottoman_Empire|Ottoman Empire]] after the [[LINK|lang_en|Italo-Turkish_War|Italo-Turkish War]] in 1911. Italian [[LINK|lang_en|Tripolitania|Tripolitania]] included the western northern half of Libya, with [[LINK|lang_en|Tripoli|Tripoli]][[CITE|2|https://dadfeatured.blogspot.com/2018/10/was-capital-of-italian-libya.html]] as its main city. In 1934, it was unified with [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Cyrenaica|Cyrenaica]] in the colony of [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Libya|Italian Libya]].

Italian Tripolitania and [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Cyrenaica|Italian Cyrenaica]] were formed in 1912, after the conquest of [[LINK|lang_en|Ottoman_Tripolitania|Ottoman Tripolitania]] in the [[LINK|lang_en|Italo-Turkish_War|Italo-Turkish War]]. In 1934, Italian Tripolitania became part of [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Libya|Italian Libya]].

A large number of Italian colonists moved to Tripolitania in the late 1930s. These settlers went primarily to the area of Sahel al-Jefara, in Tripolitania, and to the capital Tripoli. In 1939 there were in all Tripolitania nearly 60,000 Italians, most living in Tripoli (whose population was nearly 45% Italian).[[CITE|3|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5s5AW_DQhVw&feature=fvw]] As a consequence, huge economic improvements arose in all coastal Tripolitania. For example, Italians created the [[LINK|lang_en|Tripoli_Grand_Prix|Tripoli Grand Prix]], an internationally renowned automobile race.[[CITE|4|https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KMuFUccc-B0]]

In December 1934, certain rights were guaranteed to autochthonous [[LINK|lang_en|Libyans|Libyans]] (later called by [[LINK|lang_en|Benito_Mussolini|Benito Mussolini]] "Moslem Italians"[[CITE|5|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Sarti.%20*The%20Ax%20within*%20p%20190]]) including individual freedom, inviolability of home and property, the right to join the military or civil administrations, and the right to freely pursue a career or employment.

In 1937, northern Tripolitania was split into [[LINK|lang_en|Tripoli_Province|Tripoli Province]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Misrata_Province|Misrata Province]]. In 1939 Tripolitania was included in the [[LINK|lang_en|4th_Shore|4th Shore]] of the Kingdom of Italy.
The Province of Tripoli (the most important in all Italian Libya) was subdivided into:
In early 1943 the region was invaded and occupied by the [[LINK|lang_en|Allies_of_World_War_II|Allies]]; this was the end of the Italian colonial presence.
Italy tried unsuccessfully to maintain the colony of Tripolitania after [[LINK|lang_en|World_War_II|World War II]], but in February 1947 relinquished all Italian colonies in a Peace Treaty.

caption.text: This 1-lire airmail stamp, depicting an Arab horseman pointing to an airplane passing overhead, was used in 1931.

items.text: In Italian Tripolitania, the Italians made many improvements to the physical infrastructure: The most important were the coastal road between Tripoli and [[LINK|lang_en|Benghazi|Benghazi]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Libya_Railways|railways Tripoli-Zuara, Tripoli-Garian and Tripoli-Tagiura]]. Other important infrastructure improvements were the enlargement of the port of Tripoli and the creation of the Tripoli airport.
A group of villages for Italians and Libyans was created on coastal Tripolitania during the 1930s.[[CITE|6|http://www.fedoa.unina.it/1881/01/Santoianni_Progettazione_Architettonica.pdf]]

sentences.text: 1911: Beginning of the [[LINK|lang_en|Italo-Turkish_War|Italo-Turkish War]]. Italian conquest of [[LINK|lang_en|Tripoli|Tripoli]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Al_Khums|Al Khums]]. [[CITE|6|undefined]]

1912: Treaty of Lausanne [[CITE|it|undefined]]  ends the Italo-Turkish war. [[LINK|lang_en|Tripolitania|Tripolitania]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Cyrenaica|Cyrenaica]] were ceded to Italy. [[CITE|6|undefined]]

1914: Italian advance to [[LINK|lang_en|Ghat|Ghat]] (August) makes Tripolitania (including [[LINK|lang_en|Fezzan|Fezzan]]) initially under Italian suzerainty, but because of the recapture of [[LINK|lang_en|Sabha,_Libya|Sabha]] (November) by Libyan resistance men, the advance turns into retreat. [[CITE|6|undefined]]

1915: Italian reverses at the battles of Wadi Marsit, and Al Gardabiya, forced them to withdraw and eventually to retire to [[LINK|lang_en|Tripoli|Tripoli]], [[LINK|lang_en|Zuwara|Zuwara]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Al_Khums|Al Khums]]. [[CITE|6|undefined]] [[CITE|8|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Habib%20W.%20El-Hesnawi%2C%20%22The%20Story%20of%20the%20Libyans'%20Ji]]
1922:Italian forces occupy [[LINK|lang_en|Misrata|Misrata]], launching the reconquest of Tripolitania. [[CITE|6|undefined]]
1924: With the conquest of [[LINK|lang_en|Sirte|Sirt]], most of Tripolitania (except the Sirt desert) is in Italian hands. [[CITE|6|undefined]]

Winter 1927-8: Launching the "29th Parallel line operations", as a result of coordination between the governments of Tripolitania and Cyrenaica, led to the conquest of [[LINK|lang_en|Gulf_of_Sidra|gulf of Sidra]], and linking the two colonies.[[CITE|9|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=Attilio%20Teruzzi%2C%20%22Cirenaica%20Verdi%22%2C%20translated%20by%20]]
1929: [[LINK|lang_en|Pietro_Badoglio|Pietro Badoglio]] becomes a unique governor of Tripolitania and Cyrenaica. [[CITE|6|undefined]]
1934:  Tripolitania is incorporated into the [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Libya|Colony of Libya]].
1939: Tripolitania is made part of the [[LINK|lang_en|4th_Shore|4th Shore]] of the Kingdom of Italy.
